page.title: 04The Manor, St. Ouen.
page.content: The ancient manor of St. Ouen is one of the most historic landmarks in Jersey. It has stood for almost a thousand years. It belongs to the de Carteret family whose ancestors were supporters of William the Conqueror. Its long history is linked with the Royalists, especially Charles II who stayed there. Letters and personal items which beloged to Charles are on display in the house. During the Occupation of Jersey 1940-1945 it became a German barracks. The chapel in the grounds has recently been restored after its desecration during the occupation. The Manor and grounds are open to the public on Tuesday afternoons and they are occasionally used for special fetes and events. The grounds contain extensive lawns, a lake and a wooded valley.
